items.title: Trump launches 'Board of Peace' at Davos as UK, France decline

featured_image.name: Trump launches 'Board of Peace' at Davos signing ceremony ...

items.description:
President Donald Trump formally unveiled his "Board of Peace" initiative at a signing ceremony during the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, on Thursday, calling it "a very exciting day, long in the making" as he stood alongside leaders from nearly 20 nations.[1][2][3]

"We're going to have peace in the world," Trump declared. "And we're all stars." The ceremony marks the official launch of an initiative originally conceived to oversee Gaza's reconstruction but which has since expanded into a far broader organization aimed at mediating global conflicts.[1]

items.title: US and China approve TikTok spinoff deal set to close this week

featured_image.name: TikTok U.S. Sale Set to Close in January With Oracle, Silver Lake

items.description:
The United States and China have approved a deal to sell TikTok's US business to a consortium of mostly American investors led by Oracle and Silver Lake, ending a yearslong dispute between the social media platform and the two superpowers, according to Semafor.[1]

The agreement, which ByteDance CEO Shou Zi Chew outlined in an internal memo in December, is set to close this week, according to people familiar with the matter. The deal's completion would remove a sticking point in US-China relations at a time when tensions are running high and secure the platform's future for its 170 million American users.[2][3][1]

items.title: Southeast Asia's coal demand grows fastest in world, IEA says

featured_image.name: Indonesian utility PLN ordered to disclose coal plants ...

items.description:
Southeast Asia's demand for coal is growing faster than anywhere else in the world, undermining efforts to cut carbon emissions even as the region faces mounting climate change impacts, according to the International Energy Agency.

Regional coal consumption will rise by more than 4% annually through the end of the decade, the IEA reported in its latest coal market analysis. Indonesia, the world's largest coal exporter, will account for more than half of that growth, followed by Vietnam, which hit a record high of 65.43 million metric tonnes of coal imports in 2025.[1][2][3][4]

items.title: Alibaba plans IPO for AI chip unit T-Head, report says

featured_image.name: Alibaba Is Said to Plan IPO for AI Chipmaking Unit T-Head

items.description:
Alibaba Group Holding Ltd. is preparing to take its semiconductor division, T-Head, public as investor appetite for Chinese AI chip companies surges, according to a Bloomberg News report published Thursday.[1][2][3]

As an initial step, the e-commerce giant plans to restructure T-Head as a business partially owned by employees before exploring an initial public offering, according to people familiar with the matter. The timing for a potential listing remains unclear, and the process is still in its nascent stages. Alibaba's American depositary receipts rose over 4.6% in pre-market U.S. trading following the news.[4][5][2][6][1]

items.title: Saudi Arabia to host first Global Coral Reef Summit

featured_image.name: Princess Reema's views at WEF represent aspirations of young ...

items.description:
Saudi Arabia announced it will host the world's first Global Coral Reef Summit later this year, positioning the Kingdom as a leading voice in ocean conservation as coral reefs worldwide face accelerating decline from climate change.

Princess Reema bint Bandar Al-Saud, Saudi Arabia's Ambassador to the United States, made the announcement during a panel titled "The Blue Acceleration: Protecting Our Oceans at Scale" at the World Economic Forum Annual Meeting 2026 in Davos, Switzerland.[1][2][3][4]

items.title: NASA readies Artemis II for critical fueling test before lunar mission

featured_image.name: NASA's Artemis Rocket And Orion Spacecraft Rolled Out To Launchpad

items.description:
NASA's massive Artemis II rocket now stands at Launch Pad 39B at Kennedy Space Center, where engineers are conducting final preparations ahead of a critical fueling test that will determine whether the first crewed lunar mission in more than 50 years can launch next month.

The Space Launch System rocket and Orion spacecraft arrived at the Florida launch pad on January 17 after a nearly 12-hour journey from NASA's Vehicle Assembly Building, traveling at a maximum speed of just 0.82 mph aboard one of the agency's crawler transporter vehicles. Since then, technicians have been working to ready the 322-foot-tall rocket for its upcoming wet dress rehearsal, scheduled for no later than February 2.[1][2][3][4]

items.title: Chinese scientists unveil zero-carbon cooling technology

featured_image.name: High-energy-density barocaloric material could enable smaller ...

items.description:
Researchers at the Chinese Academy of Sciences have developed a novel refrigeration technology that could fundamentally change how the world cools everything from food storage to artificial intelligence data centers, eliminating the need for environmentally harmful refrigerants that have long plagued the cooling industry.

The team, led by Prof. Li Bing from the Institute of Metal Research, published their findings in the journal Nature on January 22, detailing a new cooling mechanism called the "dissolution barocaloric effect" that achieves what had been considered impossible: combining low carbon emissions, high cooling capacity, and high heat transfer efficiency in a single system.[1][2][3]

items.title: Apple developing AI pin and Siri chatbot to rival OpenAI

featured_image.name: Apple is reportedly working on an AI pin wearable that is AirTag-sized

items.description:
Apple is developing an AI-powered wearable pin and a full-fledged Siri chatbot as the company intensifies efforts to compete with OpenAI and Google in the rapidly evolving artificial intelligence landscape.

The twin initiatives, revealed in separate reports this week, mark a pivotal moment for a company that has faced criticism for lagging behind rivals in generative AI. According to The Information, Apple's wearable pin could launch as early as 2027, while Bloomberg reports that the Siri chatbot, codenamed Campos, is set to debut with iOS 27 later this year.[1][2][3][4]

items.title: Astronomers detect iron cloud, mystery object dimming distant star

featured_image.name: Astronomers just found a 'mystery object' surrounded by a metallic ...

items.description:
Two separate teams of astronomers have announced the discovery of unusual metallic structures in space, offering rare insights into the chaotic processes shaping planetary systems and the deaths of stars.

In findings announced Tuesday by the U.S. National Science Foundation's NOIRLab, researchers detected sweeping winds of vaporized metals orbiting a mystery object that dimmed a sun-like star for nearly nine months. Meanwhile, a European team revealed the presence of a massive bar-shaped cloud of iron atoms hidden inside the iconic Ring Nebula, despite centuries of observation.

items.title: Irish researchers reveal how early black holes grew to monstrous sizes

featured_image.name: Massive black hole mystery unlocked by Irish researchers ...

items.description:
A pair of studies published this week have delivered answers to long-standing cosmic mysteries, revealing how early black holes grew to monstrous sizes and clarifying where the bright glow around supermassive black holes actually originates.

Researchers at Ireland's Maynooth University reported in Nature Astronomy on Tuesday that the chaotic conditions of the early universe allowed small black holes to undergo "feeding frenzies," growing into supermassive objects tens of thousands of times the mass of the sun in just a few hundred million years after the Big Bang.[1][2][3]

items.title: Heat deaths hit record 66,825 in 2024 even as disaster deaths decline

featured_image.name: Silent killer?: Climate change fuels disasters, but deaths don't add up

items.description:
The last three years have been the hottest since the pre-industrial era, according to annual climate reports, as global temperatures continue to drive more intense heatwaves, wildfires, floods, and tropical storms. Yet despite the escalating intensity of extreme weather events, the relationship between climate change and human mortality is proving more complex than raw numbers suggest.

A new analysis by AFP, based on data from the EM-DAT global disaster database, found that more than 2.3 million people died from weather-related events between 1970 and 2025. While that figure is staggering, the death toll between 2015 and 2025 actually declined to 305,156, down from 354,428 in the previous decade.[1][2][3]

items.title: Netanyahu reverses course, accepts Trump Board of Peace invite

featured_image.name: Israel's Netanyahu to join ‘Board of Peace'

items.description:
Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu announced Wednesday that he has agreed to join U.S. President Donald Trump's Board of Peace, reversing course just days after his office criticized the initiative's leadership structure for including Turkey and Qatar without Israel's consultation.

"Prime Minister Netanyahu announced that he has accepted US President Donald Trump's invitation and will join as a member of the Board of Peace, which will be composed of leaders of the world," his office stated on social media. The decision sets up a potential clash with far-right coalition partners who have condemned Trump's Gaza governance framework.[1][2]

items.title: Trump, NATO chief announce Greenland deal framework at Davos

featured_image.name: Trump opens Davos remarks, saying he's brought 'phenomenal' US ...

items.description:
President Donald Trump announced Wednesday that he and NATO Secretary General Mark Rutte have formed "the framework of a future deal with respect to Greenland and, in fact, the entire Arctic Region," marking a potential de-escalation of tensions that have strained transatlantic relations for weeks.

The announcement came after Trump addressed the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, where he ruled out using military force to acquire Greenland for the first time since his push to acquire the Danish territory intensified. "I don't have to use force. I don't want to use force. I won't use force," Trump declared during his speech.[1][2][3]

items.title: Trump says he and NATO chief reached framework on Greenland

featured_image.name: Trump live news: US president says 'framework' reached for ...

items.description:
At a World Economic Forum panel in Davos on Wednesday, NATO's top officials delivered a unified message: despite U.S. President Donald Trump's aggressive push to acquire Greenland, Ukraine's defense against Russian aggression must remain the alliance's primary focus.

NATO Secretary General Mark Rutte, speaking alongside Polish President Karol Nawrocki and Finnish President Alexander Stubb during a panel titled "Can Europe Defend Itself?", warned against allowing the Greenland dispute to overshadow the war in Ukraine.[1][2][3]

On Greenland, "we have to make sure that that issue gets solved in an amicable way,” Rutte said. “But the main issue is not Greenland now, the main issue is Ukraine,” he added, warning that leaders risk “dropping the ball” by focusing too much on Greenland instead of Ukraine.[2][1]

items.title: Kremlin contradicts Trump's claim that Putin accepted Board of Peace invite

featured_image.name: Kremlin says Trump invited Putin to join 'Board of Peace ...

items.description: President Donald Trump claimed Wednesday that Russian President Vladimir Putin had agreed to join his Board of Peace initiative, only for the Kremlin to swiftly contradict him, stating Moscow was still evaluating the offer. The dispute unfolded at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, casting a spotlight on the controversial invitations to leaders facing international war crimes charges.

items.title: Trump rules out force for Greenland, demands negotiations

featured_image.name: Trump says no nation can secure Greenland but the US in Davos speech

items.description:
President Donald Trump delivered a defiant 72-minute speech at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland on Wednesday, ruling out military force to acquire Greenland while demanding "immediate negotiations" with Denmark over the Arctic territory and criticizing European allies as heading in the "wrong direction."

The address, widely anticipated as a pivotal moment in escalating transatlantic tensions, saw Trump claim Greenland as American territory while simultaneously attempting to reassure nervous European partners. "We probably won't get anything unless I decide to use excessive strength and force, where we would be, frankly, unstoppable. But I won't do that," Trump told the audience of billionaires, government officials, and diplomats.[1][2]

items.title: Trump rules out military force in Greenland bid at Davos

featured_image.name: Stock markets rebound after Trump's Davos speech on Greenland

items.description:
President Donald Trump told a gathering of global elites at the World Economic Forum on Wednesday that he would not deploy military force to take control of Greenland, easing fears of a transatlantic crisis that triggered Wall Street's steepest selloff in three months just one day earlier.

"I don't have to use force. I don't want to use force. I won't use force," Trump declared in his keynote address in Davos, Switzerland, adding that "people thought I would use force" and calling his pledge "probably the biggest statement I made." While ruling out military action, Trump called for "immediate negotiations" with Denmark to transfer ownership of the Arctic territory.[1][2][3][4]

items.title: Trump delays tariffs on European allies after NATO deal on Greenland

featured_image.name: Trump in Davos says NATO should allow the US to take ...

items.description:
President Donald Trump announced Wednesday he will hold off on imposing tariffs on eight European nations after reaching what he called "the framework of a future deal" with NATO Secretary General Mark Rutte regarding Greenland and the Arctic region.

The surprise announcement came just hours after Trump used his address at the World Economic Forum in Davos to reiterate demands for "immediate negotiations" on the United States acquiring the Danish territory, marking a dramatic de-escalation in a dispute that had rattled transatlantic relations for weeks.

items.title: Denmark rejects Greenland talks after Trump rules out military force

featured_image.name: Trump updates: Danish FM says Denmark, US still ‘differ’ over Greenland

items.description:
Denmark on Wednesday rejected any deal or talks to transfer its sovereignty over Greenland to the United States, hours after President Donald Trump called for "immediate negotiations" on acquiring the Arctic territory but ruled out using military force during his speech at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland.

Danish Prime Minister Lars Løkke Rasmussen welcomed Trump's statement that he would not use force but made clear that the issue was far from resolved. "It is positive that it is being said that military force will not be used. But that will not make this case go away," Rasmussen said following a meeting of the Foreign Policy Committee in Copenhagen, according to public broadcaster TV2.[1]

items.title: US envoys to meet Putin Thursday as Ukraine peace talks advance

featured_image.name: US, Russia envoys meet in Davos as Ukraine reconstruction plan postponed

items.description:
Russian President Vladimir Putin received an early draft of the U.S.-backed peace plan for Ukraine in early January through Kirill Dmitriev, head of the Russian Direct Investment Fund, according to a report by Bloomberg. The plan, which had been coordinated with Ukrainian and European partners, was delivered informally to give the Kremlin time to review the proposal and prepare feedback before expected high-level talks.[1][2]

The diplomatic maneuver comes as U.S. Special Envoy Steve Witkoff confirmed Wednesday that he and Jared Kushner, President Donald Trump's son-in-law, will travel to Moscow on Thursday to meet with Putin. "The Russians are the ones requesting this meeting. I believe this is a noteworthy indication on their part," Witkoff said at the World Economic Forum in Davos.[3][4][5][6]
